history.content:
<md>"how important GRE is"
I think it's useful when trying to standardise performance for applicants across various educational institutions, but it's nowhere near as important as your transcript. It's worth noting that for this application cycle the GRE was made optional for a lot of programs, and while I don't know if that'll be the case when you're applying, it goes to show it's something programs were willing to overlook.

"how long to prepare for it"
This really depends on what score you're aiming for and how good you are at standardised testing (which imo is not an excellent metric for intelligence, but that's beside the point). I studied for about 2 weeks at the beginning of this semester and did reasonably well, but individual experiences may vary. 

"when to prepare for it? I will be doing summer research in the next two summers so I cannot prepare for GRE then. Would it be enough to ace GRE just within the next winter break as a junior?"
I'd say winter break is a great time to study for it, so your plan to prepare for it over winter break as a junior sounds good to me! Of course like I said different people need different amounts of time to prepare depending on a variety of factors, but the 3-4 weeks of winter break seem like a good time to try getting it out of the way.


---

Note that your research experience (possible publications + letters) is really the most important thing on your application, way more important than both your GPA, GRE, and even essays. Schools are starting to put less and less emphasis on GRE anyway. As a STEM major you're set for a 170 quant, and if you like reading you should be able to get a score in the high 160s for verbal without much effort (at least that was my experience). I'd say since you're a sophomore you can start [reading](https://gre.economist.com/gre-advice/gre-verbal-section/strategies-non-native-english-speakers/boosting-your-gre-verbal-score-leisure-reading) now and take a couple of weeks to practice for the analytical writing portion in your winter break to take the GRE. (MG)
 </md>

"how important GRE is"

I think it's useful when trying to standardise performance for applicants across various educational institutions, but it's nowhere near as important as your transcript. It's worth noting that for this application cycle the GRE was made optional for a lot of programs, and while I don't know if that'll be the case when you're applying, it goes to show it's something programs were willing to overlook.

"how long to prepare for it"

This really depends on what score you're aiming for and how good you are at standardised testing (which imo is not an excellent metric for intelligence, but that's beside the point). I studied for about 2 weeks at the beginning of this semester and did reasonably well, but individual experiences may vary. 

"when to prepare for it? I will be doing summer research in the next two summers so I cannot prepare for GRE then. Would it be enough to ace GRE just within the next winter break as a junior?"

I'd say winter break is a great time to study for it, so your plan to prepare for it over winter break as a junior sounds good to me! Of course like I said different people need different amounts of time to prepare depending on a variety of factors, but the 3-4 weeks of winter break seem like a good time to try getting it out of the way.

children.subject:
Just to add my two cents, the GRE is easily the least important component of any graduate application in the sense that good letters of recommendation, good research experience (these days publications seem to be expected even from undergraduate applicants to PhD programs, which should show how competitive things have gotten), and a good transcript are all more important, in that order. However, a poor GRE score can also immediately make you less appealing for admission. 

For the verbal portion, I just practiced using Magoosh flash cards on my phone when I had free time, and I got a 170. In my opinion, the verbal section is much easier to get a higher score on than the quantitative/math section just because STEM majors kill the quant section, while there doesn't seem to be such a saturation of high scores for the verbal section. I also read in my free time, though, just for the fun of it, so that might have given me an advantage.  

I didn't do any special preparation for the quant section other than a few complete tests and scored in the high 160s. I typically score relatively poorly on math standardized tests though, at least compared to the grades I receive in mathy classes. Another comment I will make is that the quant section is, from what I can recall, literally just SAT I math all over again, which also means that it is basically useless as an indication of mathematical preparation for any type of STEM graduate education.

In my opinion, the writing portion is the most challenging section. I'd really recommend using the ScoreItNow!(tm) online practice tool for this, since a number of practice sessions come free with your GRE exam purchase and it allows you to see what a computer trained to score these tests thinks of your writing. I believe that at least one of the actual scores for your writing on the exam comes from this or a similar computer (there is also at least one human reader, I believe), so this should predict your actual performance decently. I ended up getting 0.5 lower than my average ScoreItNow!(tm) score. I think the key for doing well on the writing exam is to type quickly and be confident in your ideas, as long as there is some logic connecting them.
Again, the GRE doesn't matter much, but I'd say that you want to have a score >= 330 and an essay score >= 5. For most programs, you can also look up GRE statistics and compare accordingly
To follow up, would 325 (V155+Q170) + 4.5 be enough for Stanford or Harvard?

history.content: I'm a sophomore who is determined to go for grad school in computational/theoretical neuroscience. Could anyone offer your precious opinion and advice on how important GRE is, how long to prepare for it, and when to prepare for it? I will be doing summer research in the next two summers so I cannot prepare for GRE then. Would it be enough to ace GRE just within the next winter break as a junior?
history.subject: How long and when to prep for GRE?
